awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Applications in Modern Materials (AiMM)
awd_abstract_narration:
ID: 1359406                                   PI:  Menke, Carrie	                          ORG:  University of California-Merced

Title:  REU Site: Applications in Modern Materials (AiMM)

TECHNICAL PART:
The UC Merced REU Site (Applications in Modern Materials--AiMM) is a comprehensive, collaborative research experience for undergraduates mentored by physics, chemistry, and engineering faculty at UC Merced.  The program uses a three-pronged design of mentoring, networking, and professional development using known best practice to support women and underrepresented minorities throughout (and beyond) the program.  Participants can choose from a wide array of interdisciplinary research projects with applications in soft matter, biomaterials, nanomaterials, opto-electric materials (including solar applications), and thin films.  Participants will be closely mentored by research-active faculty who have strong extramural funding and experience in the supervision of undergraduate research students. Activities will connect participants with peers, graduate students, and faculty within AiMM and to scientific professionals at Lawrence Livermore National Lab (LLNL) and industry.  The program culminates with AiMM students participating in Annual Summer Research Symposia at both UC Merced and LLNL. 


NON-TECHNICAL PART:
Participants will be selected primarily from four year and community colleges that provide few opportunities for undergraduate research experiences.  Housing and meals will be provided in on-campus facilities, and each student will receive a stipend to cover additional expenses.  Professional development activities include active participation in faculty-led group meetings, formal and informal discussions (e.g. during weekly research seminars), and workshops on research ethics, graduate school and fellowship applications, writing personal statements, and oral and poster presentations.  These activities, in conjunction with the opportunity to participate in a cutting-edge materials research project, are designed to prepare the participants for the next steps in becoming an independent researcher in the materials field.  Contacts will be maintained with participants after their summer on the UC Merced campus as part of an assessment plan designed to measure and improve the effectiveness of the program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The Applications in Modern Materials (AiMM) REU Program at the University of California, Merced 

 

The objectives of the Applications in Modern Materials (AiMM) REU Program at the University of California, Merced were to involve a diverse set of undergraduates in cutting-edge research in the synthesis, characterization, and modeling of modern materials. Program objectives focused on participants and mentors. Participant goals included (1) contributing to the advancement of scientific knowledge, (2) increasing their research proficiency, (3) hone their scientific communication skills, which would support (4) an increase in their sense of professional identity and self-efficacy. AiMM mentors (5) applied best-known practices for working with underrepresented groups and (6) further developed their skills in designing and implementing undergraduate research projects for various timelines and students’ skill sets. Research projects included opto-electric materials, soft matter, biomaterials, and nanomaterials among others.

AiMM students also participated in Summer Undergraduate Research Institute (SURI) at UC Merced.  SURI included mostly STEM-related students funded by NSF, NIH, USDA, and the University of California.  SURI organized a summer orientation, bootcamps, and weekly professional development workshops. Students gave oral research presentations and then presented their research poster.  AiMM students also attended weekly seminars given by program faculty, postdoctoral researchers, and advanced graduate students.  Visits to the Lawrence Livermore National Lab included a tour of the facilities and attending a poster symposium with both graduate and undergraduate presenters.  The capstone of the AiMM program was SURI’s campus-wide Summer Research Symposium, where the students gave oral research presentations and presented research posters. Support of AiMM participants was extended through a Travel Scholarship awarded to the top scholars based on their symposium performance and mentor nominations. The scholarship allowed students to present their AiMM research at a regional or national conference. 

AiMM supported 27 students, mentored by 17 distinct faculty. 17 publications in peer-reviewed journals have AiMM participants as co-authors with their mentors. AiMM focused on recruiting and training students primarily from California where their home institutions were unable to offer significant undergraduate research experiences.  8 participants were from California Community Colleges and 13 had no prior research experience.  AiMM also recruited heavily to increase participation for those historically marginalized in STEM.  15 participants were women. Regarding gender, racial/ethnic affiliations, and first-generation college status, 20 of the 27 participants were included in at least one of those categories. We were able to track 23 of the 27 participants. 13 AiMM alumni are either pursuing or have obtained higher degrees in STEM and 20 are working in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2022
Modified by: Carrie Menke
